Column Comment.0: OBLIGATION: a condition of commitment on the agreement which must be fulfilled.There are many types of obligations and the fulfillment of an obligation may require achange to the agreement. e.g. offset obligation, work commitment, section 96 etc.Obligations may be financial (rental payments) or non financial (drilling, reportingetc.)
Column Comment.1: OBLIGATION SEQ NO: Unique identifier for each part or occurrence of an obligation
Column Comment.2: PAYEE PAYOR BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: The identifier for the business associatewho is the payee or payor for the obligation.
Column Comment.3: PAYEE_PAYOR: Whether the Business Associate is a payee of the obligation or apayor of the obligation.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: CHEQUE REMARK: The remark which is to be printed on the body of the check,where the information cannot be easily computed from the data model.
Column Comment.6: CONTRACT ID: Unique identifier for the contract table.
Column Comment.7: CURRENCY CONVERSION RATE: the rate applied to convert the currency from itsoriginal monetary UOM to the stored UOM. This value is valid for this row in this tableonly. When this value is multiplied by the STORED currency value, the original valueof the transaction in the original currency is obtained
Column Comment.8: CURRENCY ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: the currency in which the funds wereinitially received. When the Stored currency is multiplied by the CURRENCYCONVERSION, the value of the transaction in the original currency is obtained.
Column Comment.10: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date that the obligation payment became effective.
Column Comment.11: EXPIRY DATE: the date on which this row of data is no longer in effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.12: GROSS COST: Total amount of the obligation for this payment.
Column Comment.13: INVOICE AMOUNT: The amount on the invoice submitted for obligation payment.Note that this may not be the same as the gross or net cost of the obligation.
Column Comment.14: INVOICE NUMBER: the number of the invoice that this payment is for.
Column Comment.15: R LAND RENTAL TYPE: delay, annual or shut in payment
Column Comment.16: NET COST: net cost of the obligation payment, based on the working interest.
Column Comment.17: PAYMENT DUE DATE: Date payment is to be made
Column Comment.18: PAYMENT IND: Indicates the record is for disbursement of payments, rather thanreceipts. Y = payment, n= not payment. Allows the application to track incomingpayments as well as outgoing payments.
Column Comment.19: PAYMENT INSTRUCTION ID: unique identifier for the payment instructions.
Column Comment.20: R PAYMENT TYPE: The type of payment made, such as a rental, completion of anobligation, a submission fee etc.
Column Comment.21: R PAYMENT METHOD: The method to be used, such as direct deposit, cash, check.
Column Comment.22: PERCENT OF GROSS: Where a payment is made to several partners, the percent ofthe gross payment made on this payment to this business associate.
Column Comment.23: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.24: PROVISION ID: unique identifier for a contract provision
Column Comment.25: RATE and FEE SCHEDULE: A schedule for payments as set up by a businessassociate such as a service provider, jurisdiction or regulatory agency. Feeschedules are often used to administer the rates for rentals or for services provided.
Column Comment.26: R RATE TYPE: the type of rate charged in this schedule. Examples may includeposting fees, expenses, title search, copy charges, rentals etc.
Column Comment.27: RECEIPT IND: Indicates the record is for a receipt of payments made, rather thandisbursed. (y = payment receipt, n = not payment receipt)
Column Comment.28: OBLIGATION ID: Unique identifier for each obligation
Column Comment.29: OBLIGATION SEQ NO: Unique identifier for each part or occurrence of an obligation
Column Comment.30: RELATED OBLIGATION BUSINESS ASSOCIATE ID: Part of the foreign key for arelated obligation.
Column Comment.31: RELATED OBLIGATION PAYEE PAYOR: part f the foreign key to a relatedobligation payment.
Column Comment.32: REMARK: Narrative remark about the payment of the obligation.
Column Comment.33: R ROYALTY TYPE: a type of royalty, such as gross overriding,
Column Comment.34: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.35: STOP PAYMENT IND: Indicator to identify whether payment is to be made or not.Stop payments can be made when the address for payee is unknown, the payee is inreceivership or in arrears to you etc. Y= payment to be stopped.
Column Comment.36: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.37: SUBSTANCE SEQUENCE NUMBER: a unique sequence number added to allowhistorical information about substances that are allowed to participate in fullfillingobligations.
Column Comment.38: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.39: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.40: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.41: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.42: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.43: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.44: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
